title: Nutrition
description: Nutrition is the process by which our bodies take in and use food and liquids to maintain health, energy, and growth. The nutrients in food provide the building blocks for our body to function properly, including for energy, healing, and overall well-being.

sections.heading: Key Nutrients for a Healthy Body
sections.content:
1) Carbohydrates (Carbs)
What they are: The body’s main source of energy. Carbs are found in foods like bread, pasta, rice, fruits, vegetables, and sugars.
Why they are important: Carbs provide energy for your brain and body, especially during physical activity.
Healthy sources: Whole grains (brown rice, oats), fruits (bananas, apples), vegetables (sweet potatoes, carrots), and legumes (beans, lentils).

2) Proteins
What they are: Essential nutrients made up of amino acids that are vital for building and repairing tissues.
Why they are important: Proteins help repair body cells, produce enzymes and hormones, and maintain muscle and immune system function.
Healthy sources: Lean meats (chicken, turkey), fish, eggs, beans, lentils, nuts, seeds, and dairy products (yogurt, cheese).

3) Fats
What they are: A type of nutrient that provides energy and helps with the absorption of certain vitamins.
Why they are important: Fats are essential for energy storage, protecting organs, and supporting cell growth. Healthy fats also aid in brain function.
Healthy sources: Avocados, olive oil, nuts, seeds, fatty fish (salmon, mackerel), and coconut oil.

4) Vitamins
What they are: Organic compounds that are required in small amounts for various bodily functions like immunity and metabolism.
Why they are important: Vitamins help in processes like boosting the immune system, supporting bone health, and converting food into energy.
Sources:
- Vitamin A: Carrots, sweet potatoes, spinach.
- Vitamin C: Citrus fruits, bell peppers, strawberries.
- Vitamin D: Sunlight, fortified dairy, egg yolks.
- Vitamin E: Almonds, sunflower seeds, spinach.

5) Minerals
What they are: Inorganic elements that help the body grow and function properly.
Why they are important: Minerals like calcium, iron, and magnesium are vital for bone health, oxygen transport, and muscle function.
Sources:
- Calcium: Dairy products, leafy greens, fortified plant milk.
- Iron: Red meat, beans, lentils, spinach.
- Magnesium: Nuts, seeds, whole grains, leafy greens.

6) Water
What it is: The most essential nutrient for hydration, digestion, and temperature regulation.
Why it is important: Water helps maintain body temperature, remove waste through urine, and support overall bodily functions.
Sources: Water, fruits (watermelon, cucumber), vegetables (lettuce, celery), and other beverages.

7) Fiber
What it is: A type of carbohydrate that the body cannot digest. It helps regulate digestion and maintain a healthy gut.
Why it is important: Fiber helps prevent constipation, lowers cholesterol, and controls blood sugar levels.
Healthy sources: Whole grains, fruits (apples, berries), vegetables (broccoli, carrots), and legumes (beans, lentils).

sections.heading: Balanced Diet: How to Get All Nutrients
sections.content:
A balanced diet includes a variety of foods from different food groups to ensure you get the right nutrients for your body. Aim for:
- Fruits and Vegetables: Half your plate should be filled with fruits and vegetables, as they provide vitamins, minerals, and fiber.
- Proteins: Include lean proteins, such as fish, poultry, beans, and tofu.
- Whole Grains: Choose whole grains like brown rice, whole wheat bread, and oats instead of refined grains.
- Healthy Fats: Include sources of healthy fats, such as olive oil, avocado, and nuts.

sections.heading: Portion Control and Moderation
sections.content:
Portion sizes: Be mindful of portion sizes to avoid overeating. Eating appropriate portions helps maintain a healthy weight and supports energy balance.

Moderation: While it's important to eat a variety of foods, avoid excess consumption of unhealthy foods like sugary snacks, fried foods, and processed meats.

sections.heading: Healthy Eating Tips
sections.content:
Drink water: Aim to drink 8 glasses of water daily to stay hydrated.
Eat small meals: Instead of large meals, try eating smaller, more frequent meals throughout the day to maintain energy levels and avoid overeating.
Limit sugary drinks: Avoid sugary sodas, energy drinks, and high-calorie beverages.
Plan meals: Preparing meals ahead of time can help you make healthier choices and avoid eating fast food or junk food.
Read food labels: Check food labels for nutritional information, focusing on calories, fat, sodium, and sugar content.

sections.heading: When to Consult a Doctor or Dietitian
sections.content:
If you have specific dietary restrictions (eg, food allergies, vegetarianism, or other health concerns).
If you're experiencing unexplained weight loss or gain.
If you have a medical condition that requires a special diet (eg, diabetes, high blood pressure).
If you’re not sure about nutritional supplements or your dietary needs.

sections.heading: Common Diets and Nutritional Approaches
sections.content:
Mediterranean Diet: Focuses on fruits, vegetables, whole grains, fish, and healthy fats. Known for heart health benefits.
Plant-Based Diet: Emphasizes plant foods and eliminates or reduces animal products. Can help with weight loss and reducing chronic disease risk.
Low-Carb Diet: Reduces carbohydrates in favor of proteins and fats, often used for weight loss and managing blood sugar levels.
Keto Diet: A high-fat, very low-carb diet that may help with weight loss and some health conditions.

sections.heading: Signs of Poor Nutrition
sections.content:
Fatigue: Not getting enough nutrients, especially iron, can cause tiredness.
Unexplained weight changes: Gaining or losing weight without trying may indicate poor nutrition.
Digestive issues: Constipation or diarrhea can result from a lack of fiber or inadequate hydration.
Weakened immune system: Frequent colds or infections can result from a lack of vitamins, especially Vitamin C and Zinc.

sections.heading: What Not to Do
sections.content:
Don’t skip meals: Skipping meals can lead to overeating later and cause energy dips.
Don’t rely on junk food: Highly processed, sugary, and fatty foods provide little nutritional value and can harm your health.
Don’t follow extreme diets: Extreme or fad diets can lead to nutrient imbalances and long-term health problems.
